item.title: Canarytokens for home networks (routers again, sorry!) - Part 1
item.description: Denver, Dev and I did a spoke about Canarytokens at BSIDES Cape Town 2022. A portion of the talk covers how you could use Canarytokens to protect your SOHO networking equipment. This is what you’ll find written up below. Detecting failed authentication attempts against a Mikrotik Canarytokens are mostly built on top of two primitive alerting channels. HTTP and/or DNS requests. We can easily deploy various pre-built tokens (MS-Word, AWS, etc…), build our own detection and use either the Web Bug or DNS Canarytoken as a triggering mechanism.

item.title: Routopsy
Tinkering with a Huawei HG532s router
item.description: I had some soho routers lying around, and thought it be a good opportunity to have a go at some hardware hackzoring. I’ve written up the steps below which i took during my exploration: Step 1 - Find the UART pins Open up the router.. find the UART pins and connect your USB to UART serial converter.. Something like this should work. Step 2 - Bootloader and Memory Dump Interupt the boot process / gain access to the bootloader by pressing whichever key you need to.

item.title: about meh!
item.description: Hi! I’m, Tyron I cut my teeth building networks. Eventually found myself in offensive security, and currently tinkering in deception.
